passage:
(1) The Eiffel Tower, one of the world's most recognizable landmarks, was built for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. The tower was designed by engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company specialized in constructing metal frameworks and structures. Initially, many Parisians opposed the tower, considering it an eyesore that would dominate the city's elegant skyline.

(2) Construction of the Eiffel Tower began in January 1887 and was completed in just over two years. The tower consists of 18,038 pieces of wrought iron held together by 2.5 million rivets. The innovative design used an open lattice structure, which reduced wind resistance while maintaining strength. This engineering approach allowed the tower to reach a height of 984 feet (300 meters), making it the tallest man-made structure in the world at that time.

(3) Building the Eiffel Tower required meticulous planning and precise execution. Workers assembled each section on the ground before lifting it into place using steam-powered cranes. Remarkably, only one worker died during construction, which was an impressive safety record for the era. The total cost of the project was approximately 7.8 million francs, but ticket sales during the 1889 World's Fair covered much of this expense.

(4) Although initially intended as a temporary structure to be dismantled after 20 years, the Eiffel Tower was saved because of its value for communication purposes. During World War I, the tower intercepted enemy radio transmissions and relayed messages to troops. Today, the tower serves as a broadcasting antenna for radio and television signals throughout Paris.

(5) The Eiffel Tower has become not only a symbol of Paris but also a global icon of French culture and ingenuity. It attracts nearly seven million visitors annually, making it one of the world's most visited paid monuments. The tower has inspired replicas in various cities and has been featured in countless films, photographs, and works of art. Its enduring popularity demonstrates how a once-controversial structure has transformed into a beloved masterpiece of architectural and engineering achievement.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct past simple form of 'buy'?

If I _____ rich, I would travel around the world.
She asked me _____ I could help her with the project.
The movie was _____ boring that I fell asleep.
You _____ smoke in the hospital.
By the time we arrived, the concert _____.

She _____ be at home now; I'm not sure.

We _____ dinner by the time they arrived.

According to paragraph 1, how did many Parisians initially feel about the Eiffel Tower?

options.B: They thought it was too expensive

questions.question: What was remarkable about the safety record during the construction of the Eiffel Tower?

options.D: The tower was built without scaffolding

questions.question: Why was the Eiffel Tower not dismantled after 20 years as initially planned?

options.A: It became too expensive to dismantle
options.B: The public protested against its removal
options.C: It was valuable for communication purposes
options.D: The government wanted to keep it as a tourist attraction

questions.question: How many pieces of wrought iron were used to build the Eiffel Tower?
What does the passage suggest about the construction cost of the Eiffel Tower?

options.A: It was fully funded by the government
options.C: It was paid for by private investors
options.D: Much of it was covered by ticket sales

questions.question: When was the Eiffel Tower completed?
What engineering approach was used in the tower's design?
Approximately how many visitors does the Eiffel Tower attract annually?

options.A: It was taller than any church in Paris
options.B: It was the tallest man-made structure in the world
options.C: It was visible from 300 meters away
options.D: It was designed to be exactly 984 feet tall

questions.question: According to the passage, what role did the Eiffel Tower play during World War I?

options.A: It was used as a lookout post
